content_1: An outbreak of pandemic H1N1 (2009) virus began on a farm in Skogn on October 10. The pigs were probably infected by the owner who had been ill with flu-like symptoms. Pandemic H1N1 (2009) was confirmed in the owner. The pigs exhibited respiratory signs and Pandemic H1N1 has been identified as the cause of illness in the pigs by testing at the National Veterinary Institute. All 415 animals on the farm were culled as a precautionary measure.
content_2: Highly pathogenic H7N1 bird flu broke out at a farm for layer hens in Guadalajara on September 10. The strain was confirmed by testing at the Central Veterinary Laboratory in Algete. The farm contained 308,640 birds, of which 30,000 died of the virus and the rest were culled to prevent the spread of the disease. A 3-km protection zone and a 10-km surveillance zone have been established around the farm and there are clinical inspections on other farms in the area. The farm equipment has been destroyed along with the bird carcasses that could transmit the virus.
content_3: Cases of the H5N1 virus (avian flu) were confirmed in the commercial capital, Abidjan, on October 15. Confirmation came from the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation in Cote d'Ivoire following the return of positive test results on ravens, which were found dead in the yard of a high school on October 6. Currently, the high school is closed, and the National Institute for Public Health is monitoring 25 people who were exposed to the carcasses of the birds.
